People’s Republic of China (PRC) 
 
Thematic: Environment 
 
Category  A.  An  environmental  impact  assessment  (EIA)  was 
undertaken  and  the  summary  EIA  was  circulated  to  the  Board  in 
July 2002.  
 
The Project will reduce water pollution; protect water resources; 
promote  sustainable  economic  development;  and  improve  the 
environmental  quality,  living  conditions,  and  public  health  of 
Wuhan,  the  capital  city  of  Hubei  Province.  Wuhan  has  a 
population  of  7.3 million,  with  an  urban  center  population  of 
3.8 million.  The  Project  includes  three  infrastructure  components 
to  provide  wastewater  collection  and  treatment  in  the  areas  of 
Sanjintan  (33 km  of  sewers;  capacity  300,000 m3),  Huangjiahu 
(48 km of sewers; capacity 100,000 m3), and Luobuzui (24 km of 
sewer;  capacity  120,000  m3),  in  Wuhan;  and  a  fourth  capacity-
building  component,  including  (i) project  management,  corporate 
institutional  and  wastewater 
management,  and 
management; 
monitoring; 
(iii) development  of  a  water  quality  model;  and  (iv) establishment 
of a wastewater management training center. 
 
Wuhan is a center of industry, transportation, and communications 
with  an  urban  built-up  area  of  208 km2  out  of  its  total  area  of 
8,467 km2.  It  is  strategically  located  about  halfway  along  the 
several  thousand kilometer  reach  of  the  Changjiang  (Yangtze 
River). The Changjiang basin  is the largest river basin in the PRC 
and  it  receives  the  largest  total  wastewater  volume  of  the  seven 
major  rivers.  Though  the  river  is  often  seen  as  having  a  high 
assimilative  capacity,  the  cumulative  effect  of  the  innumerable 
point  and  nonpoint  discharges  is  deteriorating  water  quality. 
Effects of the cumulative pollution are felt throughout downstream 
reaches and the East China Sea. The growing pollution belt along 
the  river’s  banks  in  and  near  cities  is  evidence  of  localized  near-
shore  pollution.  Water  quality  in  the  Wuhan  section  of  the 
Changjiang has significantly decreased over the last 15 years. In 
the middle 1980s, water quality exceeded its designated standard. 
Since  2000,  water  quality  has  not  attained 
the  standard 
throughout  the  dry  season  and  67%  of  the  river  is  below  the 
standard  throughout  the  year.  In  2000,  Wuhan’s  wastewater 
discharge totaled about 2.05 million m3/d with domestic sewerage 
and  about  one  fourth  of  that  was  industrial  wastewater.  The  two 
existing  wastewater  treatment  plants  can  only  treat  6%  of  the 
wastewater  generated.  About  56%  of  the  rivers  and  89%  of  the 
lakes  in  Wuhan  have  been  polluted  by  organic,  nitrogen,  and 
phosphorous  wastes.  Further  existing  septic 
tanks  cannot 
effectively  treat  wastewater  due  to  the  high  population  density, 
hydrologic  conditions,  and  soil  conditions.  This,  together  with

hydrologic  conditions,  and  soil  conditions.  This,  together  with 
inadequate  sewers,  results  in  sewage  overflows  and  resultant 
poor environment/sanitary conditions. The people living in Wuhan 
are  adversely  affected  by  the  lack  of  adequate  wastewater 
management and water resources protection through the effect of 
poor water quality on public health, the living environment, risks to 
drinking  water  supplies,  and  the  negative  influence  on  economic 
development. 
 
The  proposed  wastewater  collection  and  treatment systems are 
an  integral  part  of  the  Wuhan  Urban  Wastewater  Management 
Master Plan. The goal of the master plan, which includes a total of 
13  wastewater  treatment  plants  (WWTPs),  five  of  which  are  in 
operation  or  under  construction,  is  to  bring  Wuhan’s wastewater 
treatment  rate  to  approximately  70%  by  2010.  The  systems, 
together with the Project’s capacity-building activities for corporate 
governance,  wastewater  management,  and  environmental 
monitoring,  will  contribute  significantly  to  pollution  control  and 
environmental management in Wuhan and the Changjiang basin. 
Beneficiaries  will  include  residents  of  Wuhan  and  those  living 
downstream.  
 
To  achieve  sustainable  wastewater  management  and  protection 
of  water  resources,  the  overall  objective  of  the  WWMP  is  to 
increase  wastewater  treatment  capacity  in  Wuhan  from  the 
current  6%  (19%  after  completion  of  an  ongoing  World  Bank 
project) 
to  approximately  45%  of  generated  wastewater. 
Achievement  of  this  objective  will  be  key  to  achievement  of  the 
related  objectives  of  the  WWMP  to  (i) improve  water  quality  of 
rivers  and  lakes  in  Wuhan;  (ii) protect  drinking  water  resources; 
(iii) strengthening  the  capacity  and  efficiency  of  the  Wuhan 
Municipal  Wastewater  Company  (WMWC);  (iv) improve  health 
and living standards of residents in Wuhan; and (v) improve water 
quality in downstream reaches of the Changjiang. Specifically, the 
proposed  WWMP  includes  construction  of  three  WWTPs  and 
associated collection systems as well as develop institutional and

Financing Plan 

The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will fund 96% of the foreign 
exchange  cost,  with  $83.0 million  (43%  of  total  project  cost). 
Counterpart funds will be provided by WMWC through wastewater 
tariff  revenue  of  $86.8 million  (45%)  and  local  bank  loans  of 
$23.8 million (12%).  
 

 
Allocation and Relending 
Terms 

 
Loan Amount and Terms  A loan of $83.0 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources will 
be  provided  under  ADB’s  LIBOR-based  lending  facility.  The  loan 
will  have  a  25-year  term  including  a  grace  period  of  5 years, an 
interest  rate  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  LIBOR-based 
lending  facility,  a  commitment  charge  of  0.75%  per  annum,  a 
front-end  fee  of  1.0%,  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  set 
forth in the draft Loan Agreement. 
 
The loan proceeds will be re-lent by the central Government to the 
Hubei  provincial  government  (HPG);  HPG  will  onlend  the  loan 
proceeds  to  the  Wuhan  municipal  government  (WMG)  on  the 
same terms and conditions as the ADB loan. WMG will onlend the 
loan  proceeds  to  WMWC.  All  onlending  agreements  be  on  the 
same terms and conditions as the ADB loan. WMWC will assume 
the foreign exchange and interest rate variation risks for the loan 
and  reimburse  HPG  and  WMG  for  any  intermediation  and 
transaction costs .

I. 

THE PROPOSAL  

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  for  the  Wuhan  Wastewater  Management  Project 
(WWMP). 
 
 

II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

 
A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

improve 

The PRC has made significant economic progress over the last 20 years. Real economic 
2.   
growth has averaged about 8% in this period and gross domestic product exceeded $1 trillion in 
2000.  The  urban  population  has  also  grown  rapidly:  from  190 million  in  1980  to  almost 
456 million in 2000, representing 36% of the total PRC population. Rapid economic growth and 
continuing urbanization (forecast to be 50% of the total population by 2030) are putting pressure 
on  overloaded  urban  infrastructure  and  are  causing  a  rapid  increase  in  the  demand  for  urban 
services and in environmental threats from pollution. The need for urban services is outgrowing 
the physical and financial capacity of most cities to provide adequate urban infrastructure. 
 
In  1999,  total  wastewater  generated  was  30.1  billion  cubic  meters  (m3) per year. Total 
3.   
wastewater is increasing: growth in domestic1 wastewater generation (about 65% of the total) is 
outweighing  the  reductions  achieved  in  industrial  wastewater  (about  35%  of  the  total),  as 
their  wastewater  management  practices.  Municipal  wastewater 
enterprises 
management  is  still  in  an  early  stage,  with  only  35%  of  urban  wastewater  treated  in  2000. 
Municipal wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) are the key to water pollution control, since the 
industrial treatment plants typically provide only pretreatment to a low effluent standard, prior to 
discharge  to  a  municipal  sewer.  In  the  absence  of  a  municipal  WWTP,  a  mixture  of  raw 
domestic  sewage  and  partially  treated  industrial  wastewater  is  discharged  from  the  municipal 
sewer to the nearest water body.  
 
4.    As  is  the  practice  in  industrialized  countries,  the  PRC  increasingly  manages  urban 
municipal  wastewater  with  sewerage  systems  and  treatment  plants  capable  of  treating 
pretreated  industrial  wastewater.  The  practice  results  in  large  savings  to  municipalities  and 
industries  because  of  economies  of  scale.  It  is  particularly  beneficial in the PRC as municipal 
WWTPs have suffered from poor performance as a result of weak wastewater, which results in 
lower treatment efficiency, and underutilized capacity. Risks of toxic and hazardous materials to 
WWTP  operations  and  the  environment  are  mitigated  through  regulation  of  industrial 
discharges,  to  the  municipal  system,  including  effluent  limitations,  pretreatment,  and  permit 
systems.  In  additional  to  national  regulations,2  Wuhan  has  developed  a  permit  system  for  all 
nondomestic discharges to the municipal system that will be implemented during this Project. 
 
5.    Municipal  wastewater  is  a  major  contributor  to  pollution  of  the  PRC’s  rivers  and  lakes, 
with  the  most  severe  pollution  impacts  in  the  water-short  northern  region  of  the  country.  In 
regional and administratively higher-level cities only approximately 30% of the rivers meet their 
designated  water  quality  standards  compared  with  the  objective  of  60%  established  by  the 

                                                 
1  Residential, commercial, administration, and others. 
2  National Standards – GB8978. 

 2 

Government in its 10th Five-Year Development Plan (FYP). In seven major river basins,3 52% of 
river courses do not meet the Class III standard. For river courses in urban areas, 16% are at 
the lowest Class V standard, and 36% are worse than the Class V standard. Eutrophication is 
occurring  in  75%  of  major  freshwater  lakes.  Surface-water  sources  serving  municipal  water 
supply systems are polluted to levels unacceptable under water quality standards.  
 
6.   
The  Government  has  recognized  that  adequate  environmental  protection  and  pollution 
controls are essential for sustainable economic growth. As a result, the PRC has undertaken a 
host of programs in wastewater management. Industries were ordered to treat their wastewater 
to  acceptable  standards  by  end-December  2000;  municipalities  have  been  required  under 
successive  FYPs  to  address  wastewater  collection,  treatment,  and  disposal;  and  pollution 
control plans have been developed and partially implemented for several key water basins. The 
current  FYP  directs  a  domestic  wastewater  treatment  rate  of  45%  for  regional  and 
administratively  higher-level  cities  and  a  rate  of  60%  for  cities  discharging  more  than  500,000 
cubic  meters  per  day  (m3/d).  National  guidelines  further  require  that  major  cities,  such  as 
provincial  capitals,  have  a  wastewater  treatment  rate  of  70%  by  2010.4  The  treatment  level 
required is dependent on water quality class for the receiving water. For water quality Classes I, 
II, and III, the treatment level typically expected from secondary treatment is required. 
 
The  Changjiang5  Valley  Water  Resources  Protection  Bureau  has  developed  a  basin-
7.   
wide management plan, which is in the final approval stage at the national level. The draft plan 
cites the deteriorating water quality of the Changjiang. Though the river is often seen as having 
a  high  assimilative  capacity,  the  cumulative  effect  of  the  innumerable  point  and  nonpoint 
discharges is causing the water quality to deteriorate. Effects of the cumulative pollution are felt 
throughout downstream reaches and the East China Sea. Bureau monitoring data demonstrate 
a  growing  pollution  belt  in  and  around  cities.  The  plan  sets  out  a  number  of  general  pollution 
control targets with specific targets to be developed by individual provinces and cities.6  
 
8.    Wuhan’s  extensive  water  resources  take  up  one  fourth  of  the  urban  built-up  area.  In 
2000, wastewater discharge was about 2.05 million m3/d and about 25% of that was industrial 
wastewater.  The  two  existing  WWTPs  are  only  able  to  treat  6%  of  the  wastewater  generated. 
The  large  quantity  of  untreated  wastewater  discharged  into  rivers  and  lakes  has  caused  a 
significant  deterioration  of  water  quality.  About  56%  of  the  rivers  and  89%  of  the  lakes  have 
been polluted by organic, nitrogen, and phosphorus wastes. In the middle 1980s, 100% of the 
Wuhan section of the Changjiang was Class II. Currently, none of the river reach attains Class 
III during the dry season and 67% of the river reach does not attain Class III at other times. The 
Fu River, recipient of Sanjintan’s effluent, is designated as Class IV, but generally only achieves 
Class V; eutrophication of East Lake is increasingly serious.7 Surveys carried out during project 
preparation activities noted poor environmental conditions and showed that the majority of the 
public  believed  that  unsanitary  disposal  of  sewage  has  affected  public  health.  According  to 
municipal health data, 8,463 cases of hepatitis and dysentery were reported in 2000. Wuhan is 
adversely  affected  by  the  lack  of  adequate  wastewater  management  and  drinking  water 
resources  protection  through  the  effect  of  poor  water  quality  on  public  health,  the  urban  living 
environment,  risks  to  drinking  water  supplies,  and  the  negative  influence  on  economic 
development.

The State Council, in its approval notice of the Wuhan Urban Master Plan, indicated that 
9.   
urban wastewater treatment facilities need to be constructed to control wastewater discharges 
into  rivers  and  lakes.  In  line  with  this,  the  Plan’s  water  quality  target  is  Class  II.  To  meet  this 
goal,  Wuhan  Municipal  Government  (WMG)  has  developed  a  wastewater  master  plan,  which 
includes  the  construction  of  a  total  of  13  WWTPs  and  associated  sewer  systems.8 WMG has 
also  developed  other  environmental  management  improvement  programs  including  the  “Clean 
Water  –  Blue  Sky  Action  Plan”  and  “Sustainable  Wuhan”  plan  (developed  with  United  Nations 
Environment  Programme  assistance).  Also,  WMG  has  drafted  an  overall  policy  for  improved 
wastewater management including business management.9 
 
B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

to  urban  management.  PRC  policy 

The  current  status  of  wastewater  management  in  the  PRC  provides  numerous 
10.  
opportunities to reduce water pollution, protect water resources, promote sustainable economic 
development, and improve the living conditions and public health of urban residents, including 
the poor. 
 
11.    The  Government  has  recognized  the  need  for  a  focus  toward environmental protection 
to be implemented alongside economic growth policies to meet the vision of clean, modern, and 
sustainable cities competitive in the global market place. In the past, the Government was the 
sole provider of urban services. Wastewater management practice was based on septic tanks, 
designated  open  drainage  ditches,  and  no  treatment.  Services  were  funded  through  tax 
revenue,  with  minimal  or  no  charges  levied  on  consumers.  The  use  of  septic  tanks  has  been 
shown  to  be  inadequate  for  many  urban  areas,  including  Wuhan,  due  to  high  population 
densities  and  local  hydrogeological  conditions  that  do  not  allow  for  adequate  treatment  and 
result in unsanitary overflows. Over the last decade, there has been a fundamental shift toward 
a market-based approach, enterprise provision in the delivery of infrastructure services, and an 
integrated  approach 
for 
complementary  reforms  to  support  investment  in  physical  assets.  Improvements  in  service 
delivery through investment in wastewater systems are matched by financial, governance, and 
enterprise  reform,  as  well  as  education,  awareness,  and  social  responsibility.  Although  much 
progress has been made, it is clear that the Government considers that the pace of change has 
not been quick enough and recently stated a policy requiring wastewater companies to finance 
operations  and  investments  without  government  subsidies.10  Investment  in  wastewater 
management systems is urgently needed, and social surveys demonstrate that city populations 
are  becoming  increasingly  concerned  about  the  impact  of  wastewater  pollution.  Although 
wastewater companies have been established in many cities, few are financially or managerially 
autonomous and implementation of tariff increases has been slow. 
 
12.   WMG’s commitment to management and financial reforms responds to this need. This is 
demonstrated by WMWC’s responsibility for 100% of the Project’s counterpart funding. 
 
13.   One of the ADB strategic objectives in its PRC operations is to improve the environment 
and  the  management  of  natural  resources.  ADB’s  water  policy  calls  for  integrated  water 
resources  management,  through  the  improvement  and  expansion  of  water  services,11

policy reform, regulation targets, and plant at a state level. 

 4 

(including  monitoring), 

improved  governance,  strengthened 
environmental  protection 
institutional  capacity,  and  improved  public  awareness.  The  Project  supports  these  policy 
elements  by  (i) recognizing  the  basin-wide  implications  of  Wuhan’s  wastewater  management 
programs and (ii) using an inter-disciplinary approach including financial, institutional, and social 
aspects to improve water quality. 
 
14.    ADB has made more than $1 billion-worth of investment in wastewater and water supply 
projects in the PRC.12,13 Loan projects have generally been implemented well. Lessons learned 
from wastewater projects throughout the region include requirements for (i) thorough review of 
technical  designs;  (ii) consideration  of  strategic  master  planning  in  industrial  structure  and 
consumer  behavior;  (iii) consideration  of  operation  and  maintenance (O&M), particularly local 
experience;  (iv) addressing  of  implementation  constraints  to  financial  reform,  particularly  in 
establishing autonomous wastewater entities and tariff increases; (v) addressing constraints to 
institutional  strengthening,  particularly  in  establishing  managerial  autonomy;  (vi) inclusion  of 
monitoring,  enforcement  and  regulation  issues;  (vii)  inclusion  of  education  and  training  needs, 
including  management  and  senior  level;  (viii) strong  consultation  and  community  participation, 
more  focus  on  education  and  awareness;  (ix) early  incorporation  of  resettlement  issues;  and 
(x) recognition  of  political  constraints  to  government,  economic  and  enterprise  reform.  All  of 
these relate directly to achieving strategic environmental management improvements and have 
been specifically considered in project design. A key lesson to be addressed with regard to ADB 
loan  implementation  and  disbursement  delays  is  the  need  to  (i) reconcile  differences  in  ADB 
and domestic processing procedures and (ii) initiate policy reforms during project processing so 
that  these  can  be  in  place  in  the  early  phases  of  project  implementation.  This  has  been 
addressed through careful coordination of processing schedules and regular, close consultation 
with  the  Executing  Agency  (EA)  on  policy  reforms,  and  recognition  that  these  are  key  project 
readiness indicators. 
 
15.  
Technical  and  environmental  assessment  has  confirmed  the  need  for  centralized 
wastewater  treatment  and  choice  of  sites  and  treatment  technology.  Among  others,  the 
technical  design  considers  the  Wuhan  wastewater  master  plan,  wastewater  flows  and 
appropriate plant capacity, cost-effectiveness, sludge disposal, training, and operations.14 
 
Institutional and financial reforms are currently being implemented in Wuhan, supported 
16.  
by loan requirements under the ongoing World Bank Project.15 Specific assurances, prior to loan 
effectiveness,  are  included  to  ensure  that  these  and  further  reforms,  including  tariff  increases, 
are achieved earlier than is usually achieved under ADB loans. 
 
17.   WMG is already undertaking consultation, education, and public awareness programs on 
environmental protection and wastewater management. The Project includes support for these 
programs that will assist in harnessing popular support for environmental improvements and in 
improving willingness to pay for wastewater tariffs. Politically, there is high-level support within

18.  
The  Project  is  an  integral  part  of  the  WWMP.  Wuhan’s  strategic  location  along  the 
Changjiang, and WMG’s commitment to improved wastewater management and achievement of 
government environmental  policies provide an opportunity  for  ADB  to  invest  in  environmental 
management and promote autonomous and accountable wastewater service provision. Surveys 
show that both the poor and the nonpoor are broadly in support of environmental projects and 
consider improvements in their living environment as a priority for improving their quality of life. 
 

III. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT  

Objectives and Scope  

 
A. 
 
19.  
To achieve sustainable wastewater management and protection of water resources, the 
overall objective of the WWMP is to increase wastewater treatment capacity in Wuhan from the 
current 6% (21% after completion of the ongoing World Bank project) to approximately 45% of 
generated wastewater. With an additional confirmed investment by the Government of Poland, 
the rate will be 50%.16 Achievement of this objective will be key to achievement of the related 
objectives  of  the  Project  to  (i) improve  water  quality  of  rivers  and  lakes  in  Wuhan;  (ii) protect 
drinking  water  resources;  (iii) strengthen  the  capacity  and  efficiency  of  Wuhan  Municipal 
Wastewater  Company  (WMWC)  in  commercial  principles;  (iv) improve  health  and  living 
standards  of  residents  in  Wuhan;  and  (v)  benefit  the  Changjiang.  Specifically,  the  Project 
includes  construction  of  three  WWTPs  and  associated  sewers  as  well  as  development  of 
institutional  and  management  capacity  in  the  following  areas:  (i) project  management, 
(iv) business  planning, 
(ii) wastewater  company  autonomy, 
(v) environmental  monitoring, 
(viii) public 
awareness  programs.  The  linkage  between  the  goals,  objectives,  outputs,  and  inputs  for  the 
Project are given in the project framework (Appendix 1). 
 
B. 
 
The  Project  has  three  infrastructure  components,  consisting  of  improved  wastewater 
20.  
collection  and  treatment  systems  in  the  Sanjintan,  Huangjiahu,  and  Luobuzui  service  areas  of 
Wuhan.  As  well  as  technical  studies  and  facilities  to  enhance  O&M  and  long-term wastewater 
management (see Supplementary Appendix G for  details on the components). The outputs of 
the  Project  include  (i) construction  of  WWTPs  in  three  service  areas  that  would  otherwise 
discharge about 418,000 m3/d of raw or partially treated industrial and domestic wastewater to 
surface  waters  in  the  design  year  2010;  (ii) provision  of  more  than  100 kilometers  (km)  of 
sewers and interceptors that will improve the urban environment for 1.8 million urban residents 
in 2010; and (iii) assistance in improving the water quality to achieve standards in the receiving 
waters for the treated effluents. 
 

(iii) financial  management,

(vi) water  quality, 

training,  and

 6 

1. 

Component A: Wastewater Collection and Treatment in Sanjintan  

 
21.   Component A will serve the Sanjintan area (61.4 km2) and is located on the west side of 
the  Changjiang.  Sanjintan  is  estimated  currently  to  have  a  population  of  824,000  and  is 
projected  to  have  a  population  of  921,000  in  2010.  The  facilities  will  include  33 km of sewers 
(400-millimeter  (mm)  diameter  to  2  meter  (m)  x  2.8 m  box  culvert),  and  a  WWTP  of  300,000 
m3/d  capacity.  The  proposed  Sanjintan  WWTP  will  be  a  primary  plus  secondary  biological 
anaerobic  plus  aeration  (A/O)  treatment  plant  with  adequate  sludge  treatment  and  disposal. 
Sewer rehabilitation will include the dredging and bank improvements to the Huangxiao River, 
which has served as a combined sewer. The Wuhan section of the Fu River receives 90% of the 
wastewater  of  the  Sanjintan  area  and  is  ranked  as  the  second  most  polluted  river  in  the  Main 
Urban  District  of  Wuhan.  During  the  dry  season,  the  flow  from  the  Fu  River  has  caused  the 
shutdown of the Dijiao water treatment plant (WTP) on the Changjiang (1 km south of Fu River 
and Changjiang confluence) due to its poor water quality. 
 

2. 

Component B: Wastewater Collection and Treatment in Huangjiahu 

 
22.   Serving  an  area  of  56.5 km2,  the  Huangjiahu  system  is  located  in  the  southeastern 
portion of the city and consists mainly of rural and urban districts, containing 347,000 people in 
2000 and a projected 425,000 in 2010. The facilities include 48 km of sewers (400 mm diameter 
to 1.6 m x 2.2 m box culvert), and a WWTP of 100,000 m3/d capacity. The proposed Huangjiahu 
WWTP  will  be  a  secondary  biological  (modified  carrousel  oxidation  ditch)  treatment  plant  with 
adequate sludge treatment and disposal. Wastewater is currently discharged untreated into the 
Xunsi River, which is a tributary stream to the Changjiang. During the dry season, wastewater 
from Xunsi River causes the water quality at the intake for the Pinghu WTP to deteriorate, and 
during wet season it pollutes South, Qingnin, and Tangxun lakes. South Lake is one of the main 
tourist areas and Tangxun Lake is a drinking water resource for neighboring residents. 
 

3. 

Component C: Wastewater Collection and Treatment in Luobuzui 

Special Features 

 
The Luobuzui service area encompasses approximately 30.1 km2 and is located on the 
23.  
east  side  of  the  Changjiang.  The  Luobuzui  area  population  is  expected  to  increase  from 
401,000 in 2000 to 445,000 in 2010. The proposed facilities include 24 km of sewers, 600 mm 
to  1,600  mm  in  diameter,  and  a  WWTP  of  120,000  m3/d  capacity.  The  proposed  Luobuzui 
WWTP  will  be  a  secondary  biological  (modified  carrousel  oxidation  ditch)  treatment  plant  with 
adequate sludge treatment and disposal. Depending on the season, the untreated wastewater 
from this area either flows into Qingshan Gang and then to the Changjiang, or into East Lake. 
There have been problems at the Gangdong WTP due to wastewater discharges. 
 
C. 
 
24.   Wuhan  project  management  office  (WPMO)  has  requested  that  a  portion  of  the  loan 
proceeds  be  used  for  the  development  of  a  water  quality  model  for  the  Wuhan  reach  of  the 
Changjiang, including its tributaries of the Changjiang in the area. This will be an important tool 
for improving the comprehensive wastewater management strategy for the area and predicting 
changes in water quality. A geographic information system would be included in this effort, as 
well as development of supervisory control and data acquisition system. The terms of reference 
for the modeling effort would be developed by the loan implementation consultants. The water 
quality  model  is  key  to  integrated  water  resources  management  that  is  advocated  by  ADB’s 
water policy. 
 

 7 

To  improve  its  water  quality  and  wastewater  characteristics  monitoring,  WPMO  has 
25.  
requested that a portion of the loan be used to purchase monitoring and sampling equipment. 
This  equipment  will  be  used  for  monitoring  wastewater  discharges  to  the  sewage  collection 
system,  WWTP  effluents,  and  receiving  water  quality;  it  will  provide  WPMO  and  relevant 
government  agencies  with  data  needed  to  (i) confirm  design  assumptions,  (ii) implement  a 
discharge  permit  system,  and  (iii) provide  data  input  for  the  water  quality  modeling  work  and 
operation guidelines. 
 
26.   WMWC  does  not  currently  have  a  centralized  facility  for  personnel  training.  With  loan 
conditions  requiring  WMWC  to  become  operationally  and  financially  autonomous,  it  will  be 
important  that  facilities  are  available  to  provide  the  instruction  necessary  to  effectively 
implement plant O&M. To provide for staff development and training, WPMO has requested that 
construction of a training center be included in the loan. WMWC will use the training center for 
management,  financial,  and  O&M  training.  WPMO  and  WMWC  are  developing  a  staff  training 
program and its projects will be reported to ADB in regular project progress reports. 
 
27.   Sewer  rehabilitation  is  essential  for  an  efficient  collection  system  and  transition  to  a 
separate  sewer  system.  WPMO  has  developed  a  draft  long-term  program  for  sewer 
rehabilitation. This program will be finalized during final design and certain components will be 
implemented  under  the  Project.  Sewer  rehabilitation  will  involve  (i) conversion  of  some 
combined  sewers  to  separate  sewers;  (ii) repair/replacement  of  sewers  in  poor  condition;  and 
(iii) limited dredging of two open channels that had served  as combined sewers and where the 
Project  will  include  interception  of  much  of  sewage  that  had  entered  the  channels.  The 
environmental impact assessment (EIA) addressed these sewer rehabilitation activities. 
 
28.  
To  increase  support  for  wastewater  management  improvements  and  associated  tariff 
increases, the project includes a comprehensive community awareness program. The program 
will enhance the public’s awareness of environmental and wastewater problems.

E. 
 
30.  
The  Government  has  requested  a  loan  of  $83.0 million,  about  43%  of  the  total  project 
cost,  to  finance  96%  of  the  foreign  exchange  cost  of  the  Project,  including  financing  charges. 
The loan will be from ADB’s ordinary capital resources at ADB’s LIBOR-based variable lending 
rate  for  loans,  with  a  commitment  charge  of  0.75%  per  annum  and  a  front-end  fee  of  1.0%. 
Interest during construction, the commitment fee, and the front-end fee will be capitalized under 
the loan. The loan will have a maturity of 25 years, which includes a grace period of 5 years.  
 
31.  
The Government provided ADB with the reasons for its decision to borrow under ADB’s 
LIBOR-based  lending  facility  on  the  basis  of  these  terms  and  conditions,  indicating  that  the 
currency  of  borrowing  would  be  the  US  dollar  and  noting  that  these  choices  were  its  own 
independent decision and not made in reliance on any communication or advice from ADB. 
 
32.  
The Borrower will be the PRC, which will relend  the funds to HPG. HPG will onlend to 
WMG, which will onlend to WMWC. All  relending will be on the same terms and conditions as 
the  ADB  loan.  WMWC  will  assume  the  foreign  exchange  and  interest  rate  variation  risks  for 
ADB’s  loan  and  reimburse  HPG  and  WMG  for  any  intermediation  and  transaction  costs. 

 9 

33. 
Counterpart funding will provide about 57% of the total project cost and be used to finance 
100%  of  the  local  currency  cost  and  the  escalation  contingency  for  the  foreign  exchange  cost. 
Counterpart  funding  will  be  provided  by  WMWC  through  tariff  revenues  and  PRC  bank  loans. 
WMWC  is  responsible  for  100%  of  the  counterpart  funding  which  will  assist  in  the  progression 
toward  financial  autonomy  of  the  company,  in  line  with  PRC  and  ADB  policy.  In  support  of  the

while promoting commercial principles in wastewater management. An analysis of the affordability of

F. 

Implementation Arrangements 

1. 

Project Management 

35.   WMG will be EA. A project leading group (PLG), chaired by a vice mayor of WMG, has been 
formed to provide overall guidance and support to the Project. WPMO has been established to be 
the secretariat to the PLG. The staffing and organization of the PLG includes representatives from 
Wuhan  Municipal  Water  Authority,  Provincial  Finance  Bureau,  Wuhan  Municipal  Planning 
Commission, Wuhan Municipal Finance Bureau, Wuhan Municipal Price Bureau, Wuhan Municipal 
Environmental Protection Bureau, and  related agencies. The deputy director or other officials of the 
same level of Wuhan Municipal Water Authority will be the director of WPMO. WPMO will have full-
time qualified staff. WPMO will be in charge of overall project coordination.  
 
36.  
The  designated  project  implementing  agency  will  be  WMWC.  It  will  set  up  a  project 
implementation unit, headed by the general manager, to coordinate with WPMO and facilitate timely 
implementation  of  project  activities.  WMWC  will  be  responsible  for  day-to-day  implementation 
activities. The organization of WMWC is shown in Supplementary Appendix B.  
 
37.   During  project  implementation,  WMWC  will  be  supported  by  experienced  domestic  and 
international consultants. WMWC will retain the services of design institutes, specialist proc urement 
agencies, and construction supervision companies to assist in implementation activities. WMWC will 
have  a  number  of  their  staff  trained  in  project  management  and  relevant  ADB  procedures.  Outline 
terms of reference for the loan consultancy service are given in Appendix 13. 
 

 10 

2. 

Implementation Period 

38.  
The  Project  will  be  implemented  over  a  period  of  5  years  from  June  2003  to  June  2008 
(Appendix 5). This schedule is considered realistic because the project implementation structure is 
already  in  place,  and  preparatory  works  are  under  way.  ADB’s  successful  experience  in  similar 
projects in the PRC and WPG’s in-depth knowledge and experience in wastewater pollution control 
and  wastewater  collection  and  treatment  projects  using  international  financing  indicate  that  this 
schedule is realistic and achievable. 
 

3. 

Procurement 

 
39.   ADB-financed goods and services will be procured in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines for 
Procurement.  Major  contracts  for  civil  works  and  supply  of  equipment  will  be  undertaken  through 
ADB’s  international  competitive  bidding  (ICB)  procedures,  and  equipment  packages  valued  at 
$500,000  or  less  will  be  procured  following  ADB’s  procedures  for  international  shopping  (IS).  Civil 
works  estimated  to  cost  $5 million  or  less  per  package  will  be  carried  out  under  local  competitive 
bidding  (LCB)  procedures  acceptable  to  ADB,  and  in  accordance  with  the  PRC’s  Tendering  and 
Bidding Law and procurement regulations.18 For LCB packages, local contractors have the expertise 
and  capacity  to  undertake  such  works.  Since  such  civil  works  will  involve  mainly  labor  costs, 
international contractors are unlikely to be interested in the works and the use of LCB is considered 
acceptable. In accordance with ADB requirements, foreign contractors may participate in the bidding 
for LCB contracts. Prequalification, selection, and engagement of contractors will be subject to the 
approval  of  ADB.19  As  soon  as  the  bids  received  have  been  evaluated,  the  proposal  for  award  of 
contracts will be submitted to ADB for approval. For this purpose, ADB will be furnished with three 
copies  of  (i) an  account  of  the  public  opening  of  bids;  (ii) summary  evaluation  of  bids;  (iii) the 
proposal for award; and (iv) a draft contract or letter of acceptance. Promptly after such award, ADB 
will be furnished with three copies of the contract as executed. Indicative procurement packages are 
provided  in  Appendix  6.  The  mode  of  procurement  will  be  decided  by  WMG  in  consultation  with 
ADB. The internationally tendered equipment packages will include the technical support necessary 
for  ensuring  proper  installation,  testing,  commissioning,  and  training  of  operational  staff  as  part  of 
the  related  contracts.  This  approach  assures  quality  control  in  equipment  installation  and  operator 
training,  utilizing  the  manufacturers’  and  suppliers’  technical  experts  who  are  most  knowledgeable 
about the equipment. 
 
40.   WMG has requested ADB to approve advance action to initiate the early start of preparatory 
works  so  that  mandated  treatment  rate  goals  can  be  achieved  as  soon  as  possible.20  The 
preparatory  works  include  (i) prequalification  of  contractors,  tendering,  and  bid  evaluation  for  civil 
works  contract  packages;  (ii) preparation  of  tender  documents  for  the  procurement  of  materials, 
plant,  equipment,  and  vehicles;  and  (iii) recruitment  of  international  consultants  for  construction 
supervision,  project  implementation,  and  training.21  WMG,  WPMO,  and  WMWC  were  advised  that 
issuance  of  invitations  to  bid  or  to  prequalify  under  advance  procurement  action  will  be  subject  to 
approval  by  ADB.  All  advance  procurement  actions  will  be  undertaken  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines for Procurement, and advance recruitment of consultants will be carried out in conformity 
with ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants.  The  Government,  WMG,  WPMO,  and WMWC

IV. 

PROJECT BENEFITS, IM PACTS, AND RISKS 

 
To  achieve  national  wastewater  treatment  targets,  WMG  plans  to  complete  construction  of 
51.  
nine new WWTPs24 and expand one plant to increase capacity from the present 0.38 million m3/d to 
1.4 million m3/d by 2010. The Project involves construction of three of these new WWTPs and their 
associated  sewers  and  pumping  stations.  The  total  capacity  of  the  three  plants  is  520,000 m3/d to 
serve a population of 1.8 million by 2010. These project components will collect, transport, and treat 
wastewater  for  their  catchment  areas  and  will  provide  secondary  treatment  for  effluent  to  reach 
related national standards. Assuming a construction period of 5 years, the Project, together with the 
completion  of  ongoing  and  confirmed  projects,  will  allow  Wuhan  to  achieve  treating  approximately 
56%  of  its  wastewater  by  2007.  This  is  slightly  less  than  the  nationally  mandated  2010  objectives; 
however, additional WWTPs in the planning stages are expected to bring the treatment rate to 70%. 
Municipal wastewater treatment is a key element in control of point-source water pollution, which is a 
first step toward meeting water quality standards. 
 
52.   Wastewater  interception,  treatment,  and  disposal  provide  the  best  long-term  prospect  for 
reducing  waterborne  pollution  and  improving  water  quality  conditions  in  the  rivers  and  lakes  within 
and  downstream  of  Wuhan.  The  WWTPs,  which  will  use  the  same  treatment  processes  as 
successfully used in other treatment plants, will be cost effective and reliable, and will have sufficient 
land  area  to  accommodate  plant  expansion  through  2020.  Sewer  capacities  to  be  installed  will 
accommodate  growth  in  wastewater  flows  to  2020,  thus  guarding  against  the  risk  of  overflows  of 
sewage within the urban service area and allowing any unanticipated flows in excess of the initially 
installed  biological  treatment  capacity  to  receive  preliminary  treatment  in  the  head  works  of  the 
WWTP. Thus, the risk from underestimation of the flows expected in the early years of operation can 
be accommodated by technical features to be incorporated in the WWTPs. The risks of low-strength 
wastewater  causing  operational  problems  has  been  addressed  through  the  inclusion  of  primary 
treatment and other technical features incorporated into the design.  
 
53.  
The  Project  directly  benefits  the  1.8 million  residents  and  enterprises  located  in  the  project 
area.  It  indirectly  benefits  the  entire  city  of  Wuhan,  which  is  the  capital  of  Hubei  Province  and  a 
center  for  industry,  transport,  and  communications.  Residents  of  Wuhan  will  benefit  from  an 
improved living environment and reduction in risk to drinking water supplies and better prospects for 
economic  development  and  growth.  Urban  and  rural  residents  in  downstream  reaches  of  the 
Changjiang  will  benefit  from  improvement  in  water  quality  and  associated  public  health,  amenity, 
tourism,  and  recreational  benefits.  The  number  of  downstream  beneficiaries  exceed  30 million, 
including the 20 million residents of Shanghai. 
 
A. 
 
54.  
The  Project  supports  and  strengthens  several  ADB  policy  initiatives:  (i) comprehensive 
pollution  prevention  and  control;  (ii) improved  wastewater  management  to  create  a  sustainable 
urban  environment;  (iii) enterprise  reform  and  corporate  governance;  (iv) cost  recovery  and  tariff 
reform; and (v) private sector participation. The institutional strengthening and training component of 
the  Project  will  enhance  enterprise  reform  and  corporate  governance  through  institutional 
development,  financial  management  improvement,  industrial  pollution  control,  and  construction 
supervision and training.

Institutional Strengthening 

B. 
 
55.   Consultant  advisory  services  will  be  provided  to  develop  WMWC  to  (i) be  a  properly 
constituted enterprise company, established under the provisions of PRC law and managerially and 
financially  autonomous;  (ii) act  as  the  implementing  agency,  working  and  liaising  closely  with  the 
various departments and agencies of local government; (iii) assume management responsibility for 
future O&M of project facilities, including responsibility for debt servicing and the repayment of loan 
principal;  and  (iv) assume  ownership  of  all  municipal  wastewater  assets  including  all  permanent 
works  constructed  under  the  Project.  The  proposed  corporate  structure  of  WMWC  is   given  in 
Supplementary Appendix C.  
 
56.   Potential  risks  to  developing  a  strong  WMWC  include  (i) the  failure  of  HPG,  WMG,  and 
WMWC to implement institutional reforms; (ii) the failure of WMG and WMWC to generate adequate 
public  support  to  increase  wastewater  tariffs  to  meet  cost  recovery  targets;  and  (iii) the  failure  of 
Wuhan Municipal Environmental Protection Bureau to enforce industrial pollution control regulations 
and plans, thus affecting the ability of WMWC to meet treatment standards. These risks have been 
mitigated by (i) assurances from WMG on the financial and managerial autonomy of WMWC; (ii) the 
diversity  and  frequency  of  public  participation  conducted  to  date  and  that  WMG  is  committed  to 
continue,  in  combination  with  regular  tariff  reviews  and  the  oversight  of  Wuhan  Price  Bureau;  and 
(iii) relevant  ongoing  experience  of  WPMO,  including  the  World  Bank  project  in  Wuhan,  the 
preparation  of  a  city-wide  environmental  improvement  plan,  which  incorporates  a  “Clean  Water  – 
Blue Sky” and a “Sustainable Wuhan” plan, the latter of which was developed with the assistance of 
the United Nations Environment Programme.  
 
C. 
 

Social Dimensions 

1. 

Land Acquisition and Resettlement 

 
The construction of the Project will require the permanent acquisition of 52 hectares (ha) of 
57.  
land and the temporary acquisition of 112 ha. In total, 500 households and 1,919 affected persons 
(APs)  will  be  disturbed  by  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  with  179  households  and  666  APs 
permanently affected. The main cost item for resettlement is land compensation. The total cost for 
both  land  acquisition  and  resettlement  is  estimated  to  be  CNY244 million  or  $29.3 million. 
Resettlement  impacts  have  been  identified  and  a  RP  prepared  in  accordance  with  PRC  Land  Law 
and  the  ADB  “Handbook  on  Resettlement.  The  RP  provides  a  socioeconomic  profile  of  APs  and 
addresses  issues  related  to  entitlements  of  APs’  grievance  procedures,  legal  framework, 
environmental protection, and implementation milestones (Appendix 12). Resettlement requirements 
have  been  carefully  considered  and  incorporated  into  project  design.  WMG  has  confirmed  its 
support  for  the  RP,  including  making  up  any  financing  shortfalls  of  the  implementing  agency, 
WMWC.  Given  the  relatively  small  number  of  permanent  APs,  good  experience  in  other  projects, 
and  the  strong  commitment  of  local  authorities  to  the  safeguard  policies,  it  is  unlikely  that  any 
significant problems will be encountered. 
 
58.   WMG  and  WMWC  have  implemented  ADB’s  full  disclosure  policy  for  the  resettlement 
activities, including (i) summary resettlement plan (SRP) attachment to the summary EIA, which was 
circulated to the Board in July 2002; (ii) distribution of the resettlement information booklet (RIB) to 
village offices, with appropriate notifications to APs that the booklet became available in June 2002; 
(iii) posting of the SRP on ADB’s web site; and, (iv) posting of the full RP in village offices and on the 
ADB web site upon its approval by the national Government. WPMO will establish a specific project 
resettlement  office  to  continue  public  information  activities  and  respond  to  any  questions  or 
grievances. 
 

 15 

2. 

Poverty Reduction 

 
59.  
The  Project  has  significant  poverty  reduction  impacts.  It  provides  direct  benefits  to  living 
conditions,  health,  and  job  creation,  and  indirect  benefits  to  income  poverty  that  accrue  from 
reduced health cure costs, increased productivity, and economic development. The Project directly 
and indirectly contributes to poverty alleviation. Poverty considerations are an integral part of project 
design. The poor, representing 24% of the service area population, make up a significant portion of 
the population served. Based on ADB’s established poverty line for the PRC, the proportion of poor 
in the project service area is higher than Wuhan as a whole, which has a city-wide ratio of 4.2%.25 
There will be a far wider impact than this since beneficiaries also include residents downstream of 
the  WWTPs  who  will  also  benefit  from  improved  water  quality  for  many  uses  including  drinking 
water, irrigation of food crops, fishing, and recreation. 
 
60.   As an environmental project, the living conditions for all in the service area of the Project will 
improve.  Thus,  since  the  service  area  includes  24%  poor,  and  by  definition  the  project  benefits 
accrue proportionally, about 24% of the benefits will accrue to the poor.26 
 
The Project will directly benefit poverty reduction through the provision of 7,750 person-years 
61.  
of construction jobs for skilled and unskilled laborers. WPMO has prioritized approximately 45% of 
these jobs for the poor, which will result in approximately CNY19.9 million salary accrual to the poor. 
During operations 77 full-time permanent jobs for the poor with an estimated CNY4.5 million/year in 
salaries  will  be  generated.  Project  related  services,  such  as  procurement  of  construction materials 
and  equipment  is  expected  to  provide  an  additional  840  person-year  employment,  valued  at 
CNY16.0 million  and  with  targeted  training  and  microcredit  programs  the  poor  and  women  could 
reap up to 50% of these wages. Those temporarily employed in construction operations will benefit 
from  additional  training  and  experience  that  will  provide  them  with  greater  opportunities  in 
construction of planned infrastructure development activities. By preventing the closure of industries 
that would not be able to afford the treatment requirements to river than lakes rather than the less 
severe pretreatment charges for discharge to municipal wastewater systems, the Project assists in 
the prevention of job losses. 
 
62.   Existing  Wuhan  social  protection  programs  ensure  that  the  poor  will  be  enabled  to  have 
access to wastewater systems and continued service. Subsidies to the poor include no charge for 
connection  and  up  to  CNY5  per  month  for  the  service  tariff.  Loan  assurances  require  that  these 
subsidies  be  maintained  throughout  project  implementation.  In  addition,  under  the  RP  special 
provisions have been made for the most vulnerable group through a CNY100,000 special fund that 
will provide additional monetary assistance to resettled persons in extreme poverty.27 
 
63.  
Improved  environmental  quality  will  promote  sustainable  urban  development,  for  example 
through  tourism.  The  improvement  in  water  quality  will  ensure  the  steady  development  of  a  water-
based tourism industry that depends directly on good water quality. The poor and women will benefit 
especially from the tourism activities as they make up a larger proportion of operators and vendors.

Financial Aspects 

D. 
 
64.  
Institutional  reform  to  improve  the  financial  autonomy  of  WMWC  through  direct  receipt  of 
wastewater  tariffs  is  required  prior  to  loan  effectiveness.  Tariff  increases  are  required  both  for  the 
long-term  viability  of  WMWC  and  to  provide  counterpart  funding  for  the  Project.  Incorporating  the 
other  ongoing  investment  commitments  of  WMWC,  tariff  increases  are  required prior to the end of 
2002 and again in 2005. Based on tariff increases from CNY0.4/m3 (current) to CNY0.75/m3 (2002) 
and  CNY0.91/m3  (2005),  local  loans  of  $8.4 million  are  also  required  to  fund  the  financing  cash 
shortfall in the first 2 years. These tariffs represent realistic increases,28 and an analysis of WMWC 
shows that the local loans are affordable. 
 
65.  
The financial rate of return (FIRR) is estimated at 10.4%, which compares favorably with the 
weighted average cost of capital (WACC) of 4.6%. The FIRR exceeded the WACC under sensitivity 
tests and the 6-month dollar LIBOR rate would have to double to affect the WACC. 
 
66.   An  affordability  analysis  has  been  undertaken  based  on  city-wide  official  income  data  and 
income  data  from  the  project  preparatory  TA  household  survey.  For  all  levels  of  income,  the 
combined  water  and  wastewater  tariff  was  less  than  5%  and  is  thus  affordable.  In  addition,  WMG 
Civil  Affairs  Bureau  operates  a  social  support  program  for  the  very  poorest  households,  which 
includes assistance in paying utility charges, including water and wastewater. 
 
67.   HPG and WMG have agreed to provide counterpart funds in the event that WMWC cannot 
meet  the  financing  requirements  under  the  Project.  HPG  and  WMG  have  also  agreed  to  support 
proposals for tariff increases, provided they satisfy PRC procedures for utility price increase. WMG 
has also agreed to minimum levels of financial performance for WMWC, which will be included as 
loan  covenants  and  include  capital  structure  (debt  to  equity),  debt  service  cover,  and  liquidity.  In 
addition, WMWC has agreed to undertake annual tariff reviews to mitigate the risk of poor financial 
performance or unexpected changes in operating income. 
 
E. 
 
68.  
In  accordance  with  PRC  and  ADB  policy  for  sustainable  economic  growth,  the  Project 
provides  necessary  infrastructure  for  environmental  protection  and  economic  development  in 
Wuhan.  Central  to  the  economic  analysis  is  the  fact  that  the  many  of  the  benefits  of  wastewater 
management  projects  in  large  cities  contribute  to  wider  economic  and  environmental  objectives, 
which  in  this  case  will  be  jointly  achieved  through  the  Project  and  other  investment  projects  and 
programs.  
 
69.  
The  economic  analysis  therefore  provides  an  in-depth  economic  rationale  for  the  Project, 
based  on  policy,  sector,  and  local  area  analysis.  First,  the  rationale  assesses  the  institutional 
framework for environmental protection, which is currently set through legal standards and targets, 
policies, regulations, and plans. Second, the rationale examines the Project’s role as a component of 
an  overall  master  plan  for  achieving  economic  and  environmental  objectives,  in  the  PRC,  the 
Changjiang  river  basin,  Hubei  Province,  and  Wuhan.  It  establishes  in  qualitative  terms  that  the 
Project  is  a  cost-effective  approach  for  achieving  those  objectives  and  is  the  least-cost option for 
wastewater  treatment.  The  strength  of  the  economic  rationale  and  choice  of  cost-effective 
investment is sufficient to establish the economic viability of the Project. 
 

Economic Aspects 

                                                 
28  Wuhan  Municipal  Water  Authority,  Wuhan  Municipal  Finance  Bureau,  and  WPMO  consider  that  the  proposed  tariff 
increase would be acceptable and implementable, provided that it was justified in the usual PRC hearing procedure for 
tariff increases. 

 17 

Environmental Aspects 

70.   Despite the general difficulties associated with attributing benefits to wastewater projects, the 
economic analysis includes a project economic evaluation. The evaluation uses the domestic price 
numeraire and assumes an economic opportunity cost of capital of 12%. Valued economic benefits 
included  (i) the  environmental  and  public  health  improvements  resulting  from  improvements  to  the 
collection system, using property value increases as a proxy value; and (ii) resource cost savings to 
industries.  There  are  significant  economic  benefits  that  were  not  valued  such  that  the  calculated 
economic internal rate of return (EIRR) is a lower-bound estimation of the true EIRR. Benefits that 
were  considered  qualitatively  were  (i) the  economic  growth  impacts  of  new  city  development  and 
improvement  to  water  quality,  (ii) water  resources  protection,  and  (iii) downstream  benefits  of 
nonindustrial  wastewater  treatment.  The  EIRR  was  calculated  at  16.4%  for  Sanjintan,  17.5%  for 
Huangjiahu, 16.6% for Luobuzui, and 16.9% for the Project as a whole. Sensitivity tests showed that 
the EIRR was robust, even under adverse cost and benefit scenarios. 
 
F. 
 
71.  
The  Project  will  improve  the  environmental  quality  of  Wuhan,  and  the  living  conditions  and 
public health of its citizens. Environmental improvements from the Project will provide opportunities 
for  sustainable  local  economic  and  social  development,  improved  recreation,  development  of  the 
tourism  industry,  and  will  promote  sustainable  urban  development.  The  Project  will  make 
appreciable contributions to the water pollution control program in Wuhan. The Project will also have 
positive  impacts  on  the  South,  Tangxun,  and  East  Lakes  and  the  Chang,  Fu,  Qingling,  Xunsi,  and 
Huanghu rivers and Shahu Gang, and will help safeguard the water quality of water supply sources 
and downstream cities.  Adverse impacts will be minimal and will be mitigated.  WMG and WMWC 
have  assured the implementation of the comprehensive monitoring and environmental management 
programs  that  have  been  developed  to  ensure  (i) adherence  to  PRC  laws  and  ADB  policies,  and 
(ii) that  mitigation  measures  outlined  in  the  EIA  and  Supplementary  summary  EIA  will  be 
incorporated into design and bidding documents.  
 
The  Project  will  serve  urban  areas  that  are  without  WWTPs.  Without  the  Project,  water 
72.  
quality will continue to deteriorate since individual systems cannot effectively treat wastewater given 
the  population  density,  hydrologic  conditions,  and  soil  conditions,  etc.  The  biological  treatment 
processes  selected  are  cost-effective  for  BOD,  COD,  SS,  and  phosphorus;  it  will  contribute  to 
reductions  in  eutrophication  in  Wuhan  surface  water  as  well  as  downstream  waters.  There  is  an 
accepted risk that the river reaches of the project area will not achieve water quality targets without 
the  completion  of  many  other  pollution  control  projects  in  Wuhan  and  in  upstream  areas.  This  risk 
has been reduced to manageable levels by the strong impetus and support of  the PRC and WMG 
for  environmental  improvement,  and  the  support  of  related  projects  by  other  external  funding 
agencies.29  
 
73.   Detailed environmental monitoring programs, which address monitoring of all environmental 
media,  have  been  developed  and  will  be  implemented  by  WMWC,  WPMO,  and  Wuhan  Municipal 
Price  Bureau.  The  summary  EIA  presents  completed  and  planned  public  participation  activities, 
agency  responsibilities,  staffing  needs,  major  monitoring  equipment  requirements,  a  sludge 
management plan, and monitoring programs. Necessary review and approvals of the EIA by Hubei 
Environmental  Protection  Bureau  and  State  Environmental  Protection  Administration  have  been 
completed.30 The summary EIA was circulated to the Board on 15 July 2002. 
 

                                                 
29  Appendix 3 lists other external assistance, including World Bank and Government of Poland funded WWTP. 
30  Full EIA approval by the State Environmental Protection Administration occurs concurrently with the Project Feasibility 

Study approval by State Development Planning Commission. 

 18 

Overall Assessment 

G. 
 
74.  
From the available evidence, it is clear that the integrated benefits and impacts of the Project 
will outweigh the costs, and that the Project is sufficiently robust to be beneficial under the likelihood 
of various risks occurring. The Project contributes to ADB’s long-term strategy and the international 
development goals.

Appendix 2 

 
A. 

Introduction and Scope 

SECTOR/SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS 

Sector Context  

The  sector/subsector  analysis  addresses  water  resources  protection  and  wastewater 
1. 
management,  in  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  generally,  the  Changjiang  basin,  and 
Wuhan  municipality.  The  analysis:  (i) sets  out  PRC  government  policy  and  targets  for 
environmental protection; (ii) sets out the policy and programs of the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB)  for  the  PRC,  water  resources,  and  wastewater  management;  (iii) examines the  current 
situation  of  water  resources  protection  and  wastewater  management  in  the  PRC  and  the 
Changjiang  basin;  and  (iv) examines the current situation in Wuhan, as well as targets, plans, 
and opportunities for water resources protection and wastewater management.  
 
B. 
 
2. 
Urban  development  and  economic  growth  in  the  PRC  over  the  last  two  decades  have 
been dramatic. Real economic growth has averaged about 8% over the last 20 years and gross 
domestic  product  exceeded  $1  trillion  in  2000.  The  urban  population  has  also  grown  rapidly, 
from  190  million  in  1980  to  almost  456  million  in  2000,  representing  36%  of  the  total  PRC 
population.  Rapid  economic  growth  and  continuing  urbanization  (50%  of  total  population  by 
2030) have put pressure on overloaded urban infrastructure and have caused a rapid increase 
in  the  demands  for  urban  services  and  the  environmental  threats  from  pollution.  Water 
resources protection and environmental management have become key issues in the drive for 
sustainable economic growth and improved living conditions for the population. 
 
C. 
 
3. 
In  the  past,  the  Government  was  the  sole  provider  of  urban  services.  Wastewater 
management  practice  was  based  on  septic  tanks,  designated  open  drainage  ditches,  and no 
treatment.  Services  were  funded  through  tax  revenue,  with  minimum  or  no  charges  levied  on 
consumers.  With  a  rapid  economic  growth  and  urban  expansion,  the  Government  recognized 
the need for environmental protection to be implemented alongside economic growth policies to 
meet the vision of clean, modern, and sustainable cities, competitive in the global market place.  
 
4. 
At the same time, there was a fundamental shift toward a market-based approach and 
enterprise  provision  in  the  delivery  of  infrastructure  services  and  an  integrated  approach  to 
urban  management.  PRC  policy  incorporates  the  need  for  complementary  reforms  to  support 
investment  in  physical  assets.  Improvements  in  service  delivery  through  investment  in 
wastewater  collection  system s  and  treatment  are  matched  by  financial,  governance,  and 
enterprise reform, as well as education for awareness and social responsibility.  
 
5. 
The 1996 Water Pollution and Prevention Law authorizes setting standards for ambient 
surface water quality31 and uses these standards to set targets for individual water courses. The 
State  Environmental  Protection  Administration  (SEPA)  defines  the  technical  standards  at  a 
national  level,  including  what  standards  apply  to  sections  of  rivers  or  other  water  courses of 

Government Policy  

                                                 
1  The PRC Environmental Quality Standards have five classes for surface water quality based on their use. Class I 
is  for  water  resources  and  nationally  protected  bodies  of  water.  Class  II  is  for  high-value fish production areas, 
class A protection areas, and spawning habitats for fish. Class III is for potable water resources, class B protection 
areas, general fish protection areas, and swimming areas. Class IV is for general industrial water sources and non-
 
contact recreation areas. Class I water sources are the best in quality and Class V are the worst.  

 

  

Appendix 2 

27 

strategic significance. For other rivers and water courses, the relevant environmental protection 
department at either the municipal or provincial level sets the targeted water quality class. 
 
6. 
Successive  five-year  plans  (FYPs)  set  out  targets  and  requirements  for  achieving  the 
designated  water  quality  classes,  calling  for  action  from  provincial,  municipal,  and  city 
governments  to  draw  up  specific  plans  to  address  wastewater  collection,  treatment,  and 
disposal. Pollution control plans have also been drawn up and partially implemented for several 
key  river  basins  and  areas,  but  responsibility  for  the preparation of wastewater management 
plans and the implementation of investment programs clearly lies at local government level. 
 
7. 
Regulations  are  provided  for  effluent  standards  for  industries  prior  to  discharge  to  a 
municipal sewer. Industrial facilities were required to provide adequate wastewater treatment to 
meet  specific  regulatory  pollution  limits  by  31  December  2000.  For  municipal wastewater, the 
level  of  treatment  is  determined  by  the  water  quality  class  of  the  receiving  water  and  specific 
target treatment rates. The Tenth FYP directed a wastewater treatment rate of 45% for regional 
and  administratively  higher-level  cities  and  rates  of  60%  for  cities  discharging  more  than 
500,000  m3/day.  Ministry  of  Construction  (MOC)  guidelines  32  set  more  stringent  targets  for 
larger cities, such that major cities, including provincial capitals, should have a treatment rate of 
70% by 2010.    
 
Several  other  policies,  regulations,  and  plans  also  support  the  PRC’s  framework  for 
8. 
water  quality  management.  Building  regulations  from  the  MOC  (dating  back  to  the  1980s) 
require  the  construction  of  septic  tanks  for  all  new  residential  and  other  nonindustrial 
developments;  new  developments  are  excused  from  this  requirement  if  the  discharge  is  to  a 
municipal  sewer  connected  to  a  wastewater  treatment  plant.  The  Tenth  FYP  also  requires 
substantial  progress  in  establishing  systems  of  discharge  permits,  installing  continuous 
monitoring for larger industrial discharges, and setting discharge limits based on total pollution 
loads. 
 
9. 
Clear policy direction on cost recovery and institutional reform is set out in State Circular 
1192, issued in  September  1999.  Wastewater  management  is  to  be  undertaken  by  enterprise 
companies,  and  tariffs  for  wastewater  should  be  set  at  full  cost  recovery,  although  local 
governments can implement tariff increases at a rate appropriate to local circumstances.  
 
D. 
 
The ADB Country Strategy and Program (CSP) promotes continued economic growth as 
10. 
the primary means to reduce poverty and recognizes that in the past these achievements have 
come at a considerable cost to the environment. Improving environmental protection is a main 
thematic  priority.  Wastewater  treatment  is  one  of  the  specific  investments  identified  as  an 
operational  focus.  ADB's  water  policy  supports  integrated  water  resources  management  for 
surface  water  quality  and  an  operational  strategy  for  infrastructure,  calls  for  market-oriented 
reforms,  and  directs  attention  to  urban  environmental  problems.  The  market-oriented reforms 
emphasized in the CSP include the principle of cost recovery through user charges.  
 
11. 
ADB has made more than $1 billion-worth of investment in wastewater and water supply 
projects  in  the  PRC.33  Loan  projects  have  generally  been  implemented  well.  Projects  are 

Asian Development Bank Assistance

implemented without delays and usually involve loan savings. Successive wastewater treatment 
projects  have  also  sought  to  encourage  financial  and  enterprise  reform  with  limited  success.

for  Urban  Wastewater  Tariffs  and 
Management  Study  will  assist  in  forming  appropriate  policy  reform,  regulation,  targets,  and

E. 

Wastewater Management in the People’s Republic of China 

Considerable progress in environmental management was made during the period of the 
12. 
Ninth  FYP  (1995-2000).  By  1999  the  total  discharge  volume  of  major  pollutants,  including 
chemical oxygen demand (COD) and petroleum-related products declined by 15-25% compared 
to  1995  levels.  Much  of  the  progress  was  made  in  industrial  pollution  in  line  with  government 
policy  to  target  major  point  source  polluters  first.  Many  polluting  industries  (about  5,500  state-
owned  enterprises)  were  closed  down  and  others  undertook  investment  in  on-site wastewater 
treatment, including some supported by ADB. Considerable investment has also taken place in 
municipal  treatment  plants.  By  2000,  there  were  around  400  municipal  wastewater  treatment 
plants (WWTPs) treating approximately 10 billion m3/day.  
 
13. 
Despite  the  gains  made,  total  wastewater  generation  continues  to  grow.  In  1999, 
wastewater generated was 30.1 billion m3 per year. Growth in domestic34 wastewater generation 
(about 65% of the total) is outweighing the reductions achieved in industrial wastewater (about 
35%).    About  35%  of  the  total  wastewater  generated  is  treated,  leaving  an  annual  volume  of 
over 20 billion m3 of wastewater untreated. In the absence of a municipal WWTP, a mixture of 
raw  domestic  sewage  and  partially-treated  industrial  wastewater  is  discharged  from  the 
municipal  sewer  to  the  nearest  water  body.  Designated  open  wastewater  ditches  are  still 
common  in  cities.  Municipal  wastewater  is  a  major  contributor  to  pollution  of  rivers  and  lakes, 
with the most severe pollution impacts in the water-short northern region of the country. 
 
In regional and administratively higher-level cities, only approximately 30% of the rivers 
14. 
meet their designated water quality standards compared to the Tenth FYP objective of 60%. In 
seven major river basins,35 52% of river courses do not meet the Class III standard required for 
potable water. For river  courses  in  urban  areas,  more  than  half  are  either  the  lowest  quality 
Class V or below.  Eutrophication is occurring in 75% of major fresh water lakes. Surface-water 
sources  serving  municipal  water  supply  systems  are  polluted  to  levels  unacceptable  under 
water quality standards and there is deterioration of water quality in groundwater aquifers.  
 
It is clear that, at state level, the Government considers that the progress has not been 
15. 
quick  enough.36 Considerable investment in collection systems  and municipal treatment plants 
remains  urgently  needed.  WWTPs  are  the  key  to  water  pollution  control,  since  the  industrial 
treatment plants typically provide only pretreatment to a low effluent standard, prior to discharge 
to  a  municipal  sewer.  Social  surveys  demonstrate  that  city  populations  are  becoming 
increasingly concerned about the impact of wastewater pollution. Similarly, although wastewater 
companies  have  been  established  in  many  cities,  few  are  financially  or  managerially 
autonomous and tariff increases have been slow to be implemented.

29 

 Wastewater Management in Wuhan  

Wastewater Management in Changjiang Basin 

F. 
 
16. 
The Changjiang is the largest river in the PRC. The Changjiang Valley Water Resources 
Protection Bureau has developed a basin-wide management plan, which is undergoing review 
at  the  national  level.  The  draft  plan  cites  the  deteriorating  water  quality  of  the  Changjiang. 
Though  the  river  is  often  seen  as  having  a  high  assimilative  capacity,  the  cumulative  effect  of 
the  innumerable  point  and  nonpoint  discharges  is  deteriorating  water  quality.  Effects  are  felt 
throughout  downstream  reaches  and  the  East  China  Sea.  Red  tides37 have occurred and are 
becoming more frequent. Bureau monitoring data demonstrate a growing pollution belt of near-
shore pollution in cities along the river. The plan sets out a number of general pollution control 
targets with specific targets to be developed by individual provinces and cities. 
 
G. 
 
17.  Wuhan,  the  capital  city  of  Hubei  Province,  lies  about  halfway  along  the  course  of  the 
Changjiang.  Wuhan  has  extensive  water  resources,  which  take  up  25%  of  the  urban  built-up 
area.  In  response  to  state  requirements  and  in  accordance  with  the  basin  plan,  Wuhan 
Municipal Government (WMG) adopted a target of Class II for the Wuhan stretch of the river, set 
out in the Wuhan Urban Master Plan. To meet the water quality target for the Changjiang and 
comply  with  government  regulations  to  treat  70%  of  municipal  wastewater  by  2010,  WMG  is 
implementing the Wuhan Municipal Wastewater Master Plan. The plan divides the city into 13 
drainage  areas  and  targets  the  dense  urban  areas  for  priority  investment  in  a  cost-effective 
approach.  Wuhan  has  also  developed  other  environmental  management  improvement 
programs including the “Clean Water – Blue Sky Action Plan” and “Sustainable Wuhan” plan. It 
has  also  drafted  regulations  for  lake  protection  and  pollution  discharges  as  well  as  a  sewer 
discharge  permit  ordinance,  and  is  developing  comprehensive  sewer  connection  and 
rehabilitation programs.  
 
The Wuhan Municipal Wastewater Management Company (WMWC) was established in 
18. 
1995  and  wastewater  tariffs  were  introduced  in  1996.  Two  wastewater  treatment  plants  were 
completed  in  1998  but  they  are  only  able  to  treat  about  6%  of  the  2.05  million  m3/day 
wastewater  generated.  About  56%  of  the  rivers  and  89%  of  the  lakes  have  been  polluted  by 
organic,  nitrogen,  and  phosphorus  wastes.  Water  quality  in  the  Wuhan  section  of  the 
Changjiang  has  deteriorated.  In  the  middle  1980s  it  was  Class  II.  Currently,  none  of  the  river 
reach attains Class III during the dry season and 67% of the river reach fails to attain Class III at 
other  times.  The  Fu  River,  recipient  of  Sanjintan’s  effluent,  is  classified  as  Class  IV,  but 
generally  only  achieves  Class  V.  Drinking  water  resources  are  at  risk.  Eutrophication  of  East 
Lake is increasingly serious.38  
 
19. 
Figure A2.1 and Table A2.1 show the progress and location of the 13 planned treatment 
plants for the drainage areas that make up the Wastewater Master Plan. From a slow start, the 
Master Plan is well under way but further investment is urgently needed. Tariffs have increased 
but,  as  part  of  World  Bank  loan  assurances  for  an  ongoing  WWTP  project,  remain  well  below 
full cost recovery levels. Implementation of financial and enterprise reforms are overdue but will 
be  completed  by  the  end  of  the  year.  The  Project  will  assist  in  funding  three  WWTPs  and 
associated  wastewater  collection  systems  and  further  implement  tariff  and  enterprise  reform.

Appendix 2 

Under  the  Project,  about  26%  of  total  wastewater  will  be  treated,  bringing  the  total  to  45%  by 
end-2007. Tariffs are proposed to be at full cost recovery by collecting revenue from the users.  
 
20.  Wuhan will meet the 70% target if other WWTPs in the planning stage are implemented. 
These  include  one  funded  out  of  World  Bank  loan  savings,  one  funded  by  the  Government  of 
Poland, and two proposed build-operate-transfer  schemes for economic development zones. 
 
21. 
The Project therefore is a critical component of the Wuhan Municipal Wastewater Master 
Plan,  which  is  also  a  fundamental  part  of  the  Wuhan  Urban  Master  Plan,  since  without 
investment  in  wastewater  facilities,  the  planned  urban  expansion  will  not  go  ahead.  While  the 
Project will not enable WMG to immediately reach the target rate of 70%, it is an important step 
in enabling that target to be met in conjunction with other projects. The Project will also assist in 
the implementation of other investments through cost recovery reform and assisting WMWC in 
achieving financial and corporate autonomy.

FINANCIAL ANALYSIS 

Financing Plan 

Introduction and Scope 

Cost Estimates and Asian Development Bank Loan Size 

A. 
 
The financial analysis includes: assessment of cost estimates and loan size; assessment 
1. 
of  the  affordability  of  the  financing  plan;  tariffs  and  cost  recovery;  financial  appraisal;  and 
affordability.  Important  to  the  financial  analysis  was  consideration  of  other  recent  and  ongoing 
wastewater investment being undertaken by Wuhan Municipal Wastewater Company (WMWC), 
including projects supported by loans from the World Bank and the Government of Poland. 
 
B. 
 
Total project costs are $193.6 million, including $83 million in foreign exchange costs to 
2. 
be funded by the Asian Development Bank (ADB). In line with the ADB graduation policy for the 
People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  (group  A),  the  loan  size  is  determined  subject  to  financing 
percentages  for  specific  items;  the  overall  foreign  exchange  component;  and  the  amount the 
Government  wishes  to  borrow.  Since  ADB  will  finance  the  interest  during  construction,  the 
estimated loan size will change with fluctuations in the interest rate. The interest used for loan 
preparation was the current 5-year swap rate plus the ADB  fixed spread of 0.6%, giving a total 
interest charge of 3.95%. 
 
C. 
 
3. 
PRC  policy  on  wastewater  management  is  fast  moving  toward  commercial  principles, 
supported by institutions including the ADB. Recent ADB projects in the PRC generally included 
equity  contributions  from  the  Government  as  a  major  source  of  counterpart  funds,  whilst  tariff 
increases were proposed to increase gradually to reach full cost recovery by project completion, 
thereby ensuring long-term financial viability. Government policy is evolving quickly and a recent 
statement from key Ministries39 involved in wastewater management has strengthened the PRC 
policy  commitment 
tariffs  and  establishing  commercially  sound  wastewater 
companies.  Government  funding  for  wastewater  investment  projects  is  now  discouraged. 
Rather,  in  an  effort  to  speed  up  enterprise  and  tariff  reform,  wastewater  companies  are  now 
expected  to  fund  all  activities  from  their  own  resources,  including  finance  for  capital 
construction.  
 
4. 
In addition to the policy direction from State level, Wuhan Municipal Government (WMG)  
has also provided commitments to the World Bank for financial autonomy of WMWC. WMG has 
interpreted  this  to  mean  that  WMG  should  not  provide  counterpart  funds  for  the  ADB  Project. 
The  proposed  financing  plan  includes  counterpart  funds  financed  100%  by  WMWC,  through 
tariff  revenues  and  local  loans.  Taking  into  consideration  the  financing  requirements  of  other 
projects,  the  plan  requires  that  tariffs  increase  from  the  current  CNY0.4/m3  to  CNY0.75/m3 
before the end of 2002 and 0.95/m3 before 2005. Recognizing that the increases are subject to 
the  normal  procedures  for  price  increases  in  the  PRC,  Wuhan  Municipal  Water  Authority 
(WMWA),  WPMO,  Wuhan  Municipal  Finance  Bureau  and  Wuhan  Municipal  Price  Bureau 
considered that these increases are reasonable and subject to the normal procedures for price 
increases  in  the  PRC,  would  be  socially  and  politically  acceptable.  Tariff  revenues  in  the  first 
year of Project construction are supplemented by local loans of CNY69.6 million ($8.4 million), 

to  raising
