Tariffs and Cost Recovery 

which  are  considered  to  be  affordable  given  that  the  debt  service  coverage  ratio  remains 
satisfactory. 
 
5. 
Since  tariff  increases  are  required  for  Project  construction,  WMG  has  provided  a 
guarantee that if WMWC cannot provide the necessary counterpart funds then WMG will fund 
the  shortfall.  This  guarantee,  included  in  the  assurances,  mitigates  the  financing  risk  and 
ensures  that  counterpart  funding  will  be  available  for  the  Project,  while  promoting  commercial 
principles  in  wastewater  management.  A  detailed  analysis  of  the  affordability  of  counterpart 
funds, including the cash-flow requirement, is included in Supplementary Appendix I.  
 
 
D. 
 
6. 
Wastewater  tariffs  are  collected  by  the  Wuhan  Municipal  Water  Supply  Company 
(WMWSC).  Although  bills  for  water  supply  and  wastewater  are  issued  separately,  they  are 
delivered  together.  Currently,  wastewater  revenue  is  passed  from  WMWSC  to  the  Wuhan 
Municipal  Finance  Bureau.  WMWC  is  given  a  part  of  that  revenue  as  a  direct  subsidy, 
depending on estimated operational costs and investment plans. In accordance with assurances 
provided to the World Bank as part of the Hubei Urban Environment Project, tariff revenues will 
be passed directly to WMWC, which will be responsible for its own finances. This arrangement, 
which is a condition of ADB loan effectiveness, will be in place before the end of 2002 and will 
assist in ensuring financial autonomy of WMWC. 
 
7. 
Wastewater  tariffs  have  been  in  place  in  Wuhan  for  more  than  5  years and tariffs for 
water  and  wastewater  have  gradually  increased.  Tariffs  for  wastewater  are  relatively  low 
compared to other cities in the PRC, reflecting the low rate of treatment (currently at only 6%).

In  accordance  with  government  policy  and  ADB  recommendations,  tariffs  have  been 
estimated,  based  on  the  principle  of  full  cost  recovery  for  WMWC  by  2007.  This  includes

including  the  ADB  loan.  Allowances  are  made  for  doubtful  debts  at  15%.  Calculated  required 
tariffs  in  2008  are  CNY0.83/m3  (constant  2002  prices)  and  CNY0.95/m3  (current  prices).40 
Based on tariffs calculated for other World Bank and ADB projects in the  PRC, required tariffs 
for cities with 100% treatment are usually in the range of CNY1.3/m3 to CNY1.8/m3. Since, after

Given  the  requirement  for  tariff  revenues  to  also  provide  counterpart  funding  for  the 
Project, tariff increases will need to take place before the end of 2002 and 2003 to provide funds 
for  2003  and  2004  respectively.  The  tariffs  used  in  calculating  the  financing  plan  are

E. 
 
Project financial appraisal was undertaken jointly for the project components since they 
10. 
will  be  operated  by  WMWC  and  the  same  tariff  will  apply  across  the  city.  Since  WMWC  also 
owns and operates other wastewater facilities, including treatment plants, funded by the single 
tariff, the project financial appraisal assesses the viability of this Project to WMWC. 
 
The  financial  appraisal  compares  the  financial  internal  rate  of  return  (FIRR)41  to  the 
11. 
weighted  average  cost  of  capital  (WACC);  and  the  average  incremental  cost  (AIFC)  to  the 
average incremental revenue (AIFR). Sensitivity tests were undertaken for increases in costs, 
decreases  in  revenues,  and  delays  in  revenues.  The  appraisal  was conducted using constant 
2002 prices. A detailed analysis is included in Supplementary Appendix I.  
 
The  WACC  was  calculated  based  on  ADB’s  latest  guidelines.42  The  nominal  costs  of 
12. 
funds  were  assumed  to  be  2.73%  for  the  ADB  loan,  based  on  the  5-year swap rate of 3.35% 
plus  ADB’s  fixed  spread  of  0.6%;  8.0%  for  internal  cash,  and  6.3%  for  the  local  commercial 
bank  loans.  Nominal  costs  were  adjusted  for  tax  and  inflation.  For  both  the  ADB  loan  and  the 
commercial bank-funded portions, the calculated rate was less than 4% and thus the minimum 
allowable rate of 4% was applied to these funding sources. The overall WACC was 4.6%.  
 
13. 
Incremental revenue was calculated using total WMWSC water sales since the proposed 
wastewater tariffs will apply to all water users, not just those living in the project area. However, 
not  all  the  tariff  increase  from  the  existing  level  (CNY0.4/m3)  can  be  attributed  to  the  Project. 
Under  the  ongoing  World  Bank  project,  tariff  increases  are  also  required.  The  calculation  of 
incremental revenue assumed that an increase in the tariff to CNY0.6/m3 was attributable to the 
World Bank project43 and the residual increase was attributable to this Project. 
  
14.   Operation  and  maintenance  costs  include  personnel  (10%  of  total  operation  and 
maintenance),  energy  costs  (36%),  chemicals  (7%),  administration  (2%),  repairs  and 
maintenance (44%), and other (1%).  
 
15. The FIRR was 10.4%, which exceeds the WACC of 4.6%. The FIRR exceeds the WACC for 
all  sensitivity  tests.  Interest  rate  sensitivity  for  the  ADB  loan  was  calculated.  The  FIRR  and 
associated sensitivity tests are given in Table A7.2.

An  affordability  analysis  was  undertaken  to  assess  whether  the  Project  is  affordable  to 
residential  consumers.  In  line  with  ADB  guidelines,  the  affordability  criteria  were  set  at  a 
maximum  of  5%  of  monthly  household  income  for  combined  water  and wastewater charges.  
Household  income  data  from  the  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  household  survey, 
which covered the project area, was compared to official citywide household income distribution 
data from the Wuhan Statistical Yearbook 2001. The two data sets were reasonably similar, with 
the  household  survey  showing  slightly  lower  levels  of  income  than  the  official  citywide  data, 
particularly at the low income range.  
 
17. 
The  residential  water  sales  data  were  extracted  from  domestic  water  sales,  which 
includes other categories. Residential water sales were 269 million m3 in 2001. The population 
served is estimated at 6.7 million, including 5.4 million registered population (11 urban districts) 
and  1.3  unregistered  population.  Water  sales  are  estimated  at  110  liters  per  capita  per  day 
(lpcd).  To  be  conservative,  no  allowance  was  made  for  lower  water  use  for  lower  income 
families and income growth was assumed to be zero. Household charges were calculated using 
the  proposed  wastewater  tariff  and  existing  water  tariffs.  It  was  possible  to  use  existing  water 
tariffs as a proxy for future water tariffs since there are no plans for water tariff increases and 
WMWA considers that water tariffs are already at the full cost recovery rate.  
 
Table A7.3 shows the affordability analysis using the city-wide official income data. For 
18.  
the average household, the charges amount to 0.9% of monthly income. The results show that 
the  proposed  charges  are  also  affordable  at  all  income  levels,  since  the  combined  charge 
constitutes  less  than  5%  of  monthly  household  income.  Although  the  income  data  from  the 
household  survey  was  lower,  using  the  same  approach,  the  results  show  that  even  for  the 
poorest  10%  of  households,  the  combined  charge  is  less  than  5%.  In  addition,  for  the  very 
poorest households, WMG has an established subsidy program, run by the Civil Affairs Bureau, 
which assists in paying for basic services, including water and wastewater.

Appendix 9 

ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 

Introduction, Approach, and Scope  

Project Description and Beneficiaries 

 
A. 
 
1. 
The  economic  analysis  was  undertaken  using  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
guidelines.44 The approach takes into consideration the fact that the proposed Project is not a 
stand-alone investment, but is an integrated part of an ongoing city, municipal, and basin-wide 
environmental  program,  whereby  overall  environmental  goals  are  jointly  achieved  with  other 
investments. For projects of this nature, where the impact is very difficult to  attribute to specific 
projects or components, often the economic justification relies on strong rationale, consideration 
of  alternatives  and  appropriate  assessment  of  project  risk.  The  economic  analysis  therefore 
provides an in-depth economic rationale based on policy, sector, and local area analysis, which 
examines  the  least-cost  approach  to  achieving  environmental  objectives.  Despite  the  general 
difficulties  associated  with  attributing  and  valuing  benefits  of  wastewater  management,  the 
economic  analysis  also  includes  a  project  economic  evaluation  and  calculation  of  economic 
internal rates of return (EIRRs); and an assessment of project sustainability and risk. A detailed 
economic analysis is included as Supplementary Appendix H.  
 
B. 
 
2. 
The proposed Project forms an integral component of the Wuhan Municipal Wastewater 
Master Plan. The Project will provide collection systems and secondary wastewater treatment 
plants for three of the 13 identified drainage areas in Wuhan. There are two existing wastewater 
treatment  plants  (WWTPs)    in  Wuhan,  which  currently  provide  a  treatment  rate  of  6%;  three 
WWTPs  are  under  construction,  which  will  increase  the  treatment  rate  to  19%  by  the  end  of 
2002.  The  proposed  Project  will  add  an  additional  26%,  giving  a  total  treatment  rate  of  45%. 
Four  more  WWTPs  are  in  various  stages  of  preparation,  including  two  build-operate-transfer 
(BOT)  schemes,  but  these  are  unlikely  to  be  completed  before  the  end  of  project 
implementation. Together, all the proposed WWTPs will bring the total treatment rate to 70%. 
 
The  Project  will  directly  serve  a  collection  area  of  148  km2  and  1.8  million  people  (by 
3. 
2010).  However, the impact of the Project is far wider. The investment in wastewater facilities 
undertaken by Wuhan Municipal Government (WMG) is a fundamental part of the Wuhan Urban 
Master Plan (WUMP) through (i) providing necessary infrastructure for new development areas; 
(ii) improving  the  existing  living  environment  and  public  health;  (iii) contributing  to  urban 
development schemes; and (iv) contributing to the overall vision for a clean, modern city through 
sustainable  economic  growth.  The  number  of  indirect  beneficiaries  includes  the  urban 
population  of  Wuhan  (5.4  million)  and  the  municipality  (7.5  million).  Populations  downstream 
include  the  municipality  of  Shanghai  with  a  population  of  over  20  million.  There  are  also 
proposals  to  undertake  a  project  that  will  divert  part  of  the  Changjiang  to  the  Taihu  Lake,  to 
assist in water quality and this would link the Project to the ADB Suzhou Creek Project, which 
addresses the pollution of the downstream water course, flowing from Taihu through Shanghai 
to the Huangpu River.

Appendix 9

C. 

Economic Rationale, Policy Analysis, and Assessment of Alternatives  

The  institutional  framework  for  managing  environmental  quality45  in  the  People’s 
4. 
Republic of China (PRC) consists of two main components: (i) legal standards and targets; and 
(ii) policies  regulations  and  plans,  aimed  at  meeting  those  targets.  The  1996  Water  Pollution 
and  Prevention  Law  provides  the  legal  basis,  under  which  the  State  Environmental  Protection 
Administration  designates  standards  (or  targets)  that  apply  to  key  water  courses,  through  a 
rigorous technical process. Although public consultation in setting the targets was limited, there 
is general public support for environmental policies, and thus the justification for chosen targets 
is sound.  
 
5. 
The target for the Wuhan section of the Changjiang under WUMP is Class II. In addition, 
the state guidelines require that Wuhan reaches a wastewater treatment rate of 70% by 2010. 
The Changjiang Valley Water Resource Bureau draft management plan cites the deteriorating 
quality of the river and the growing pollution belt and calls for individual cities and municipalities 
to draw up their own plans for pollution control. The Wuhan Wastewater Master Plan, including 
the Project, is a key component of WMG’s environmental program.46 While the Changjiang has 
a high assimilative capacity, the cumulative effects of numerous point and nonpoint discharges 
are deteriorating water quality. While it is not possible to measure the incremental impact of the 
Project  on  water  quality,  it  is  clear  that  without  the  Project,  neither  the  ambient  water  quality 
target nor the target treatment rate will be achieved.  
 
6. 
PRC environmental policy adopts a cost-effective approach to wastewater management. 
Major  point  source  polluters  were  targeted  first  and  much  progress  was  made  through  the 
implementation  of  the  Ninth  Five-Year  Plan.  In  Wuhan,  this  included  Wuhan  Steel  Mill  and  a 
petrochemical plant. The next targets for wastewater management have been industries, which 
were required to provide adequate wastewater treatment by December 2000 and large centers 
of population including Wuhan. Selection of projects within Wuhan has focused on the areas of 
dense  population  first,  with  the  proposed  Project  providing  necessary  collection  and  treatment 
for  the  next  three  areas  of  identified  priority.  The  chosen  projects  were  also  the  least-cost 
solution in terms of technical treatment options.  
 
D. 
 
7. 
Project evaluation was undertaken for each component separately and for the Project as 
a  whole.  The  economic  evaluation  was  undertaken  using  the  domestic  price  level  and 
numeraire and constant 2002 prices. Financial costs are converted to economic costs using a 
standard conversion factor of 0.89. Valued economic benefits included (i) the environmental and 
public health improvements resulting from rehabilitation and extension of the collection system, 
using  property  value  increases  as  a  proxy  value;  and  (ii) resource cost savings to industries. 
The  timing  of  property  value  increases  were  based  on  a  conservative  view  of  the  pace  of 
development.  There  are  significant  economic  benefits  that  were  not  valued  such  that  the 
calculated  EIRR  is  a  conservative  estimate  of  the  true  EIRR.  Benefits  that  were  considered 
qualitatively were (i) the economic growth impacts of new city development, (ii) water resources 
protection, and (iii) downstream benefits of nonindustrial wastewater treatment. The EIRR was 
calculated at 16.4% for Sanjintan, 17.5% for Huangjiahu, 16.6% for Luobuzui, and 16.9% for the 
Project as a whole.

ENVIRONMENTAL ANALYSIS 

Introduction  

A. 
 
Population  growth  and  economic  development  have  contributed  to  the  degradation  of 
1. 
the quality of the aquatic environment in Wuhan. Fifty-six percent of the rivers and 89% of  the 
lakes  in  Wuhan  have  been  polluted  to  different  levels  by  organic  materials  and  nutrients.  the 
Changjiang  water  quality  has  deteriorated,  which  has  led  to  adverse  impacts  to  water  supply 
sources, reduced suitability of the rivers for their classified use as well as general environmental 
degradation.  The  majority  of  wastewater  is  now  treated  in  individual  systems  before  it  is 
discharged to drainage channels (including open channels and streams), soil, and groundwater. 
A full environmental impact assessment (EIA) has been prepared in accordance with People’s 
Republic  of  China  (PRC)  Law  and  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  policies.47 The  summary 
environment  impact  assessment  (SEIA),  with  the  summary  resettlement  plan  (SRP)  as  an 
attachment was circulated in June 2002. 
 
B. 
 
2.  Key  features  relevant  to  wastewater  management  are  as  follows.  The  Project  area  has 
(i) a subtropical monsoon climate with abundant rainfall; (ii) many rivers, lakes, and ponds with 
more  than  25%  of  the  municipality  covered  by  water;  (iii) mostly clay and sandy clay soil; and 
(iv) shallow groundwater. Groundwater is the major water source for industries; surface water is 
source  for  all  other  uses.  The  major  water  bodies  affected  include  the  Changjiang  (Wuhan 
section),  the  Fu  River  (Wuhan  section),  and  East  and  Tangxun  lakes.  Aquaculture  is  a  major 
activity  in  the  area.  The  Changjiang  is  the  ultimate  receiving  water  body  for  all  wastewater 
treatment plant (WWTP)  effluents. The cumulative effect of point and nonpoint discharges have 
contributed to its degradation. Local pollution is common in river reaches in major cities. Table 
A10.1 summarizes existing water quality.

B. 

Poverty Analysis  

Proposed Classification: Other  

Poverty analysis has been treated as an integral part of project design and based on quantitative and qualitative 
methodologies. The project design has included the analysis of poverty data at country and province levels and involved 
field-poverty assessments and stakeholder consultations.  
 
The Project will have direct and indirect poverty reduction effects on its rural and urban beneficiaries. Based on the project 
preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) household survey of the beneficiary population in the project area, approximately 
23.7% of those live below the Asian Development Bank (ADB) poverty line (5.4% rural, 24.3% urban).48 The construction 
and operation of the Project will create many employment opportunities for the local population. During construction, 7,750 
person-years  of  employment  will  be  generated  with  an  estimated  3,340  person-years  to  be  filled  by  the  poor;  during 
operations 77 full-time jobs for the poor with an estimated CNY4.5 million/year in salaries will be generated. Project-related 
services, such as procurement of construction materials and equipment, are expected to provide an additional 840 person-
years of employment, valued at CNY16.0 million and with target training and microcredit programs the poor and women 
could reap up to 50% of these wages. The implementation of the Project will lead to improvement in sewage service and 
sanitary conditions and will contribute to the reduction in morbidity and mortality rates of waterborne diseases and savings 
in  associated  medical  costs  and  loss  of  healthy  working  days.  As  an  example,  each  case  of  dysentery  results  in 
approximately  CNY480  of  direct  medical  costs  and  30  lost  workdays.  These  benefits  are  greater  for  children,  elderly, 
women, and the poor as they are more vulnerable to these diseases. Improved health and quality of life will promote local 
economic  development.  Moreover,  agricultural  production  losses  will  be  reduced  and  depressed  prices  for  agricultural 
products will be mitigated through the improved quality of irrigation water. The improvement in water quality will ensure the 
steady development of the water-based tourism industry, which is to a large extent water-based and depends directly on the 
water  quality.  Tourism  brings  multiple  benefits,  including  increased  income  and  employment  opportunities,  to  the  local 
communities.  Women  and  poor  will  benefit  from  the  tourism  activities, as they  are  involved  in tourism  as  operators and 
vendors.  The  reduced  pollution  and  improved  water  quality  in  the  receiving  waters  will  reduce  the  costs  of  treatment  for 
Wuhan’s  existing  and  future  water  treatment  plants,  which  will  be  passed  onto the consumers. Socioeconomic loss from 
severe  water  logging  can  be  mitigated.  The  improved  environment  can  serve  as  a  major  contributing  factor  to  increased 
investment.  Wuhan  has  demonstrated  that  improving  the  environment  is  an  effective  way  for  reducing  poverty  and 
improving living conditions (TA5939-REG: Strategies for Poverty Reduction Through Urban Environmental Improvements). 
Importantly, subsidies will be provided to households below income poverty levels.

SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT PLAN  

Introduction 

 
A.  
 
1. 
This  document  summarizes  the  complete  resettlement  plan  (RP)  for  the  proposed 
Wuhan Wastewater Management Project to be funded by the Asian Development Bank (ADB). 
The RP was prepared in accordance with (i) the PRC Land Administration Law 1998 and related 
laws  and  regulations;  and  (ii) ADB’s  involuntary  resettlement  policies  and  its  requirements  as 
outlined in ADB’s Handbook on Resettlement. 
 
2. 
The  Project  is  located  in  three  urban  districts  of  Wuhan  Municipality  and  will  finance 
construction  of  three  wastewater  treatment  facilities,  including  Sanjintan,  Luobuzui,  and 
Huangjiahu  projects.  The  Sanjintan  wastewater  treatment  plant  (WWTP)  is  located  in 
Zhangjiadun  Company,  Dongxiihu  District,  with  61.4  km2  of  service  area  and  824,000  service 
population,  5  pumping  stations,  and  32.9  km  of  sewers  (including  5.4  open  channel 
rehabilitation).  The  Luobuzui  WWTP  is  located  in  Beiyangqiao  Village,  Heping  Township, 
Hongshan  District,  with  total  30.1  km2  of  service  area  and  401,000  service  population,  4 
pumping stations, and 24.2 km of sewers. The Huangjiahu WWTP is located in Shenli Village, 
Qinglin  Township,  Hongshan  District,  with  56.5  km2  of  service  area  and  347,000  service 
population,  4  pumping  stations,  and  47.9  km  of  sewers  (including  rehabilitation  of  7.9  km  of 
open channels).  
  
B.  
 
The  Project  will  affect  3  districts,  4  townships,  3  subdistricts,  and  13  administrative 
3.

more  detail  on  (i) temporary  effects  and  (ii) socioeconomic  conditions  and  views  of  APs,  the 
Project will permanently acquire 782 mu49 of land, including 590 mu of vegetable fields, 187 mu 
fish  pond,  and  5  mu  housing  plot.  Most  of  permanent  land  acquisition  (97%)  will  be  used  for 
three WWTPs, and the remaining for the pumping stations. In addition, about 1,786 mu of land 
will  be  occupied  temporarily  for  sewer  construction,  with  36%  of  vegetable  land,  25%  of 
fishpond  and  the  rest  is  dry  land  or  nonagricultural/urban  land.  Land  acquisition  and 
resettlement  will  directly  affect  500  households  and  1,919  affected  persons  (APs),  including 
permanent losses for 121 households and 468 APs, and temporary losses for 379 households 
and 1,451 persons as shown in Table A12.1.

Policy Framework and Compensation Standards 

Along  with  land  acquisition,  a  total  of  70,803  m2  of  structures  will  be  demolished, 
4. 
including 2% frame structures, 77% brick concrete, 14% brick wood, and the rest as earth wood 
or  simple  structures.  A  total  of  321  households  and  1,253  APs  will  be  temporarily  affected, 
including 236 households (839 persons) from rural areas and 83 households (365 persons) from 
urban areas. Rural households will only  need  to  be  relocated  within  their  own  villages  to  the 
housing  plots  provided  by  the  villages.  Urban  households  will  be  assigned  new  apartments 
within  the  same  area.  A  total  of  25  enterprises  will  be  affected  by  the  land  acquisition  and 
building demolition  and  only  three  of  them  will  be  relocated  within  the  existing  village.  The 
remaining  enterprises  are  affected  through  loss  of  supplemental  structures,  like  warehouses 
and storage facilities. The buildings will be restored with cash compensation provided under the 
Project.  
  
C.  
 
5. 
For  people  unavoidably  affected  by  the  Project,  the  resettlement  objective  is  to  ensure 
attainment  of  equal,  or  better,  livelihoods  and  living  standards  than  without  the  Project.  The 
Executing  Agency  (EA),  Wuhan  project  management  office  (WPMO),  will  ensure  that  any 
people losing land, housing, or other assets due to the Project will be assisted in restoring their 
income  and  living  standards.  Following  consultation  with  local  governments  and  general 
practice in Wuhan, a set of generous compensation standards that are near the top of the 1998 
Land  Law  range  was  adopted  by  WPMO.  For  permanent  land  acquisition,  a  total  of  21  times 
average  annual  output  value  (AAOV) will  be  provided  with  10  times  AAOV  for  land 
compensation,  10  times  AAOV  for  resettlement  subsidy,  and  1  time  AAOV  for  green  crop 
compensation. Based on average yields, the compensation rates will be set at CNY126,000/mu 
for  vegetable  land,  dry  lands,  and  other  noncultivated  land,  and CNY80,000/mu for fish pond. 
For temporary land occupation, 2 times AAOV will be provided with 1 time for annual loss and 1 
time  for  restoring  land  to  original  conditions.  For  lost  structures,  replacement  value  will  be 
provided with CNY1,400/m2 for frame structure, CNY900/m2 for brick concrete, CNY600/m2 for 
brick wood, and CNY400/m2 for earth wood structure. In addition, relocated households will be 
provided with transfer assistance, including moving allowance, early moving bonus, etc. 
 
D.  
 
6. 
In  order  to  avoid  land  acquisition  in  the  most  densely  populated  areas,  efforts  were 
made  in  close  consultation  with  local  officials  and  village  committees  during  the  feasibility 
studies to minimize the resettlement impacts. For APs, the resettlement strategy encompasses 
the replacement of housing, infrastructure, and income. People losing housing will receive direct 
compensation  based  on  replacement  value  of  their  lost  structures.  Due  to  limited  land 
acquisition, most of these  people  will  be  resettled  within  their  own  villages,  provided  with  new 
housing  sites  free  of  charge,  and  connected  with  essential  infrastructure  (e.g.,  water,  sewer, 
road, gas, and electricity). Relocated urban households will be given cash compensation that is 
sufficient  to  purchase  replacement  apartments  in  the  project  area.  Affected  enterprises  will  be 
provided  with  cash  compensation  covering  lost  structures,  lost  wages,  lost  profit,  and  an 
alternative site for reconstruction.  
 
7. 
Those  affected  by  permanent  land  acquisition  who  are  primarily  concentrated  in  the 
WWTP site will receive compensation. Two approaches for economic rehabilitation will be taken 
based  on  different  village  conditions.  For  Sanjintan,  since  the  affected  Zhangjiadun  Company 
will  have  sufficient  farmland  left  after  land  acquisition,  land  redistribution  will  be  carried  out  to 
ensure  that  each  individual  still  has  1.5  mu  farmland  after  land  acquisition.  In  addition,  the 
resettlement  subsidy  will  be  distributed  equally  among  all  members  in the company, and land 
compensation will be used to improve farm conditions and create nonfarm opportunities for the

The RP includes grievance redress arrangements. In the case of  grievance, AP submits

within 2 weeks, then the AP can go to the township government for redress. If still unresolved 
within 2 weeks, the PRO or Wuhan Municipal  Land Administration Bureau will try to achieve a 
solution  directly  within  3  weeks.  The  final  redress  could  be  sought  in  the  civil  courts  in 
accordance with the PRC Civil Procedure Act, within 15 days of receipt of the PRO decision.
